awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: High efficiency multi-material heat sink/storage by additive manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an additive manufacturing process to produce solid-state heat management systems using shape memory alloys (SMAs).  SMAs benefits from a solid-solid phase transformation, which is of interest in many applications of heat sink/storage. However, there are challenges in processing of SMAs such as nickel titanium (NiTi) using conventional methods, which limits its design to simple geometries. The proposed technology overcomes these challenges by fabrication of SMAs through additive manufacturing methods.  Heat management systems using NiTi may be additively manufactured using 3D printing technology.  This technology may have a wide range of applications including heat sink/storage for satellites, telecommunication antennas, and consumer electronics.  There is a growing need to develop better solid-state heat management systems driven by the need for safer and more environmentally friendly systems.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an additive manufacturing method to fabricate shape memory alloys into complex geometries.  Shape memory alloys such as nickel titanium (NiTi) offer solid-solid phase change, which reduces the risk of leakage observed with other phase change materials.  In addition, NiTi as a phase change material with high volumetric latent heat as well as excellent corrosion resistance has been reported to improve the efficiency for thermal storage systems.  The proposed technology couples phase changing NiTi material with a high thermal conductivity material such as copper to produce energy storage and conversion systems.  It has been demonstrated that using a sandwich of NiTi/Copper can increase the time to reach the critical temperature when compared to a copper heat sink alone.  This result indicates that this may be used in a wide range of applications including heat sink/storage for satellites, telecommunication antennas, and overshoot controllers. Moreover, the reversible solid-solid martensite transformation eliminates the risks of leakage and reduces the cost of maintenance of these applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Developing heat sink/storage devices using phase change materials (PCMs) has the potential to shift the paradigm in this technology toward safer and more efficient devices. In 2021, the global market size of PCMs was valued at USD 477 million and it is projected to grow to USD 1,004 million by the year of 2026. Compared to other PCMs with solid-liquid and liquid-gas phase transformations, NiTi shape memory alloys offer a safer alternative by reducing risk of leakage due to their solid-state phase transformation. However, the low thermal conductivity of NiTi presents a major barrier for its effective use as PCM in energy storage and heat management devices.

Leveraging our expertise in NiTi shape memory alloy and its manufacturing, we proposed and investigated the additive manufacturing of NiTi to couple it with copper as a high thermal conductive material, as schematically shown in Figure 1 a), to enhance thermal conductivity for its effective use in energy storage systems. Considering the wide range of applications of heat sink/storage, included overshoot controller, solar water heaters, and battery thermal management systems, additive manufacturing offers the flexibility to fabricate customized devices tailored to specific needs.

After developing our proof of concept shown in Figure 1 b), and fabricating NiTi/Cu parts, we participated in NSF I-Corps national program to evaluate the potential application of our technology. With guidance from I-Corps instructors and mentors, researchers refined their customer discovery skills, conducted market research, and identified key industry needs. We investigated different technologies and discussed the potentials of our devices and its ability to overcome the drawbacks of current devices with engineers and sales managers of various companies. 

Initially, we focused on battery thermal management systems in electrical vehicles. However, after extensive market research, we pivoted from our primary applications due to the difficulties in reaching the market and their lack of interest due to the absence of immediate need of our technology for their devices.

We found a promising application in aerospace application, specifically for heat management system in cube satellites. By further engaging with industry engineers, we identified the shortcomings of current systems and outlined key modifications needed to optimize our technology for satellite applications. 

The ability to customize NiTi/Cu heat management devices using additive manufacturing presents a significant advantage for cube satellite thermal management. This approach enhances the lifespan and provides a safer, more efficient, and environmentally friendly alternative to existing solutions.


Last Modified: 03/05/2025
Modified by: Mohammad H Elahinia

Image
  • a) a schematic of NiTi-Cu specimen, and b) fabricated NiTi, Cu, and NiTi-Cu samples.
    Mohammad Elahinia, University of Toledo
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Mohammad H Elahinia
    The designed samples to validate our technology.
